title: If 4 is the only solution to the equation X^2-5X+K=0, what is the value of K? - Quora

response.answer_text: Under the current wording of this question, I am going to assume that you are looking for a real number kk that satisfies these constraints. I will claim that there is no such kk that satisfies the equation x2−5x+k=0x2−5x+k=0 such that 44 is the only solution. Here’s a simple proof by contradiction: Assume x=4x=4 is the only solution to the equation x2−5x+k=0x2−5x+k=0. We know as a direct result that (4)2−5⋅4+k=0(4)2−5⋅4+k=0 k=4k=4 Therefore, our original equation is now x2−5x+4=0x2−5x+4=0 But wait a second, this equation also has a solution of x=1x=1 which contradicts our previous assertion that x=4x=4 is the only solution. Therefore, no such kk can exist that satisfy these constraints.

For a quadratic equation x2−px+q=0x2−px+q=0 to have a single solution, the left hand side needs to be a square polynomial. Hence it is necessary (and sufficient) to have the condition q=(p2)2q=(p2)2 fulfilled. In which case your quadratic polynomial reduces to (x−p2)2(x−p2)2 and the solution is x=52x=52. x=4x=4cannot be the only solution. Please note that the condition that x=4x=4 is a solution does already determine the value of k. Maybe that is what you meant by your question. If x2−5x+kx2−5x+k has 4 as a root, then the polynomial is divisible by (x−4)(x−4). Carrying out the division, or using trial and error, multiplying (x−4)(x−r)=x2−(4+r)x+4r(x−4)(x−r)=x2−(4+r)x+4rshows you already that r=1,r=1, your solutions are 1 and 4, and k=4k=4

By plugging X=4 into the equation, we have 4^2–5*4+K = 0, or 16–20+K=0, ie, K=4. However, X=4 is not the only solution to X^2–5X+4=0. By factorization, we see that (X-4) (X-1) = 0, ie, X=1 or X=4. That is, there is NO UNIQUE SOLUTION for this equation if X=4 is one solution. The quadratic equation delineates that the ‘determinant’ (or discriminant function), b^2–4ac, must be zero to have a unique solution (-b/2a). In this situation, the discriminant is (-5)^2 - 4(1)(K) = 25–4K. If we set that to zero, the only unique solution occurs if K=25/4. (And X=5/2 is the only solution).

There is no valid answer to this question. We can prove this in a very simple way. If 4 is the only solution, then it is, by definition, a solution. This means that plugging in x=4 MUST yield 0. (4)^2–5(4)+K=0 16–20+K=0 K=4 However, if we factor the equation x^2–5x+4=0, we get (x-4)(x-1)=0, giving both 4 and 1 as solutions. This contradicts the premise of the question, that 4 was a unique solution to the equation.

Well, I assume you mean if x=4x=4 is the only solution to the equation. If so, we get the following. 42−5(4)+k=042−5(4)+k=0 16−20+k=016−20+k=0 −4+k=0−4+k=0 k=4k=4 It's mainly just inputting the value of xx into the equation to see what kk is. However, I have the feeling that x=4x=4 is not the only solution. x2−5x+4=0x2−5x+4=0 (x−4)(x−1)=0(x−4)(x−1)=0 x=1,x=4x=1,x=4 So if you were given x=1x=1 instead, you would still be able to find k=4k=4. Note: I get the feeling this is a homework problem. If so, please attempt to do your homework before asking for help.

You have too many constraints on your problem. Either 4 is the only solution to an unspecified quadratic equation or 4 and another number are solutions to a quadratic equation of the specified form. It’s kind of like asking “if x = 0, then what multiple of x is 5?” There will be those who demonstrate that no such value of K exists, but it’s actually quite obvious if you consider what it is you are asking. Hint: The x-coordinate of the vertex of a parabola does not depend on K.
Assuming K is just a constant and not dependent on X then simply plug in 4 for X to get: 16 – 20 + K = 0 Then you can solve for K.
Put 4 inplace of x.16-20+K=0K=4.Easy as you like
